nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: Friday evening. You’re in the hallway, one shoe off, one shoe on. Your partner’s child is standing by the door, backpack on, waiting for the co-parent to arrive.
You hear your partner say from the living room, “Put that back in your room, they don’t like toys in the hallway.”
The child hesitates and glances at you, like you’re the judge of what’s allowed.

choices.label: Reassure the child and gently clarify the rule.
Stay silent and let your partner handle it.
Correct your partner in front of the child.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: A few minutes later, the co-parent arrives. The hallway feels tight: shoes, backpacks, and invisible history all in one place.
The co-parent hugs the child and throws a quick glance at you – polite, but distant.
Your partner says, “We’re trying to keep the hallway clear now, right?” and looks at you for backup.

choices.label: Offer a neutral, practical summary instead of taking sides.
Make a small joke to diffuse the tension.
Point out how often the child leaves things everywhere.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: Later that night, the house is finally quiet. The hallway is empty again, but the feeling isn’t.
Your partner sits at the kitchen table and sighs.
“I feel like you’re either too strict or too soft,” they say. “I never know what to expect from you with the rules.”

choices.label: Acknowledge the confusion and ask for one small area to define together.
Defend your intentions and explain why you reacted the way you did.
Point out all the times you felt undermined as a step-parent.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: By the end of the conversation, it’s clear: nobody has ever sat down to say out loud what your role as a step-parent is supposed to be.
The hallway incident wasn’t really about shoes. It was about who gets to say “we” when it comes to the child.
Act 1 closes with a gentle realization: if the three adults don’t name the boundaries, the child will keep guessing where they are.

choices.label: Move into Act 2 – focusing on the child’s loyalty tug-of-war.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: A few weeks later, it’s Sunday evening. The child is back from the co-parent’s home and seems unusually quiet.
They hover near you while you cook, then blurt out:
“At Mom’s house I don’t have to ask about snacks. Here I have to ask *you* and *them*.”

choices.label: Validate the child’s feelings and thank them for telling you.
Explain the rule differences like a teacher, focusing on structure.
Remind them that "every house has different rules" and change the subject.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: Later, after the child goes to play, your partner comes in from a call with the co-parent.
Their voice is tight. “They said you’re confusing the kid. That you’re acting like a second parent instead of a support.”
The phrase “acting like a second parent” lands like a stone in your stomach.

choices.label: Name how that comment hits you, without attacking anyone.
Ask your partner what *they* think, before reacting to the co-parent.
Suggest limiting your involvement to avoid drama.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: As the evening goes on, the “Who am I allowed to be?” question keeps floating between you and your partner.
Is your role more like a coach, a bonus parent, a housemate, an aunt/uncle?
You both realize nobody has ever said this out loud with the co-parent present, and the child has been left to interpret the silence.

choices.label: Propose a three-adult conversation focused on the child’s sense of safety.
Ask to at least define some language you and your partner will use consistently.
Decide to wait and “see how things evolve” without any plan.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: Act 2 closes not with a “win”, but with a clearer map:

• The child is being loyal to *all* of you.
• Each home has different rules and different emotional climates.
• Your role as step-parent is real, but unnamed roles create extra stress.
You and your partner agree: whatever happens next needs to be less about who is right, and more about what will make life predictable for the child.

choices.label: Move into Act 3 – drafting a more stable “two-home” plan.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: You’re all at a neutral place – a café near the park. You, your partner, and the co-parent.
The child is within sight on the playground, laughing with other kids. For once, all three adults are in the same frame.
You take a breath. This could become just another round of blame. Or something else.

choices.label: Open with appreciation for what each adult is trying to do.
Start by naming the child’s stress and your wish to reduce it.
Lead with specific complaints about past conflicts.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: Slowly, the conversation turns toward practical questions:

• Who explains rule differences to the child?
• How will you talk about your role when new partners enter the picture?
• What words do you *all* feel comfortable with for “step-parent”?
It’s not perfectly smooth. There are eye rolls, pauses, and some hard swallows. But it’s happening.

choices.label: Suggest writing down 3 shared principles to test for a month.
Ask for a commitment to check in again after a few weeks.
Insist on resolving *everything* in this one conversation.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: By the end of the meeting, you haven’t redesigned the whole family system. But something is different:
There are a few written agreements. A plan to talk again. And a shared sentence you all agree to use when the child asks about rules or loyalty.

It sounds something like:
“You don’t have to choose between us. All of us are trying to keep you safe, even if our houses work a little differently.”

choices.label: Close the scenario with a brief reflection on your preferred next step.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
text: This scenario doesn’t end with a perfect blend of families.
Instead, it ends with something more realistic and more powerful:

• clearer language for your role,
• a few shared principles between the adults,
• and a slightly lighter load on the child’s shoulders.
You can replay the scenario making different choices to explore how trust, tension, and child stress shift over time.
